title: Review: Actors shine in subversive, rockin’ ‘Hair’
text:
Review: Actors shine in subversive, rockin’ ‘Hair’ Paul Hyde , phyde@greenvillenews.com 7:14 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 Furman Theatre’s joyous production of “Hair” continues through Oct. 25. Pictured are, left to right, Dayanari Umana, Salvo Donzella, Patrick Fretwell, Clark Spillane, Kenzie Wynne, Daniel Hoilett, Elli Caterisano, Clair Ruble, Matt Reeve and Courtney Dorn. (Photo: Sam Nelson) 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Furman Theatre’s “Hair” packs a wallop. 
You can quibble about aspects of this ambitious production, which opened Thursday, but you have to hand it to Furman’s plucky student actors for embracing this 1968 rock musical with go-for-broke gusto and commitment. 
The hyperactive, 18-member ensemble energetically captures the playful and subversive spirit of this musical celebration of 1960s counterculture. 
As peaceniks and protesters, the actors on the stage of the Furman Playhouse beam with idealism and bristle with in-your-face attitude. 
Backed by a hard-charging band, they also deliver Galt MacDermot’s now-classic rock numbers — “Aquarius,” “Hair” and “Let the Sunshine In,” among others — with full-throated flower power. 
Cheerfully profane and pointedly irreverent — with some nudity to boot — “Hair” will probably rattle some conservative sensibilities. But that, after all, was the point of the show in the beginning: to challenge conventional public opinion on war, race, drugs, sexuality, religion and patriotism. 
The story, by James Rado and Gerome Ragni, centers on a tribe of rebellious hippies dedicated to peace, love, freedom and happiness in a world torn by war, bigotry, conformity, political hypocrisy and environmental degradation. 
Of course, as young people, they’re also consumed by thoughts of their romantic entanglements even as they’re burning their draft cards and bras. 
“Hair” can be a chaotic enterprise but its experimental, unbridled style is part of its appeal. Like its free-spirited characters, “Hair” balks at the traditional rules. 
Director Maegan McNerney Azar brings an admirable degree of clarity to the proceedings while eliciting broad, uninhibited and joyous performances from her actors, whose enthusiasm can’t be contained within the bounds of the stage. They frolic in the aisles, frequently interacting with the audience and coaxing a few patrons onto stage. 
Dance plays a big part in the show as well. The swaying, hyper-kinetic choreography, by Azar and Madeline Jazz Harvey, is terrific. 
The show really shines when the entire ensemble gets into the act, as in “Aquarius,” “Ain’t Got No Grass,” “Hair” and “Hare Krishna.” 
Now, for those aforementioned quibbles: A few solos on opening night sounded as if they could have benefited from some more rehearsal time. In addition, from where I sat, it seemed to me that the band occasionally drowned out the singers. This is a loud, rockin’ show — as it should be — but the vocals should always rise above the musical accompaniment. Diction was inconsistent — sometimes crisp, sometimes muddy. 
Perhaps the most dated part of “Hair” is the long-winded hallucinatory section in Act 2. Azar, to her credit, brings a creative momentum to this surreal riff on the Vietnam War. 
Salvo Donzella is appropriately assertive, even manic, as the grandstanding Berger. 
Patrick Fretwell is sympathetic as the ambivalent Claude, leading some of the show’s most stirring songs of affirmation (“I Got Life”) and helplessness (“Where Do I Go”). 
Courtney Dorn, as the earnest protester Sheila, brings a vibrant voice to songs such as “I Believe in Love” and “Good Morning, Starshine.” 
Kenzie Wynne is endearing as the flibbertigibbet Crissy, sweetly singing “Frank Mills.” 
Carolyn Carrier-McClimon leads the excellent six-member band. 
Margaret Rose Caterisano is responsible for the colorful hippie costume design. 
This zesty production of “Hair” continues through Oct. 25. For tickets, call 864-294-2125.
